Probabilistic Kernel Function for Fast Angle Testing

Kejing Lu1â€ƒâ€ƒChuan Xiao1,2â€ƒâ€ƒYoshiharu Ishikawa1
1Nagoya Universityâ€„ 2Osaka University
Abstract

In this paper, we study the angle testing problem in high-dimensional Euclidean spaces and propose two projection-based probabilistic kernel functions, one designed for angle comparison and the other for angle thresholding. Unlike existing approaches that rely on random projection vectors drawn from Gaussian distributions, our approach leverages reference angles and employs a deterministic structure for the projection vectors. Notably, our kernel functions do not require asymptotic assumptions, such as the number of projection vectors tending to infinity, and can be both theoretically and experimentally shown to outperform Gaussian-distribution-based kernel functions. We further apply the proposed kernel function to Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search (ANNS) and demonstrate that our approach achieves a 2.5X âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼ 3X higher query-per-second (QPS) throughput compared to the state-of-the-art graph-based search algorithm HNSW.

1 Introduction

Vector-based similarity search is a core problem with broad applications in machine learning, data mining, and information retrieval. It involves retrieving data points in high-dimensional space that are most similar to a given query vector based on a specific similarity measure. This task is central to many downstream applications, including nearest neighbor classification, recommendation systems, clustering, anomaly detection, and large-scale information retrieval. However, the high dimensionality of modern datasets makes efficient similarity search particularly challenging, highlighting the need for fast and scalable vector computation techniques.

Among the various similarity measures for high-dimensional vectors, the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, cosine distance, and inner product are the most commonly used in practice. As discussed in Norm_range_LSH ; norm-explicit-quantization ; peos , it is often possible to pre-compute and store the norms of vectors in advance, allowing these measures to be reduced to the computation of the angle (inner product) between two normalized vectors, thereby highlighting the central role of angle computation. On the other hand, in many real-world scenarios, we are not concerned with the exact value of the angle itself but rather with the outcome of an angle-based comparison, which is referred to as the angle testing. Specifically, given a query vector ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}bold_italic_q and data vectors ğ’—ğŸsubscriptğ’—1\bm{v_{1}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ’—ğŸsubscriptğ’—2\bm{v_{2}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ’—ğ’—\bm{v}bold_italic_v on sphere ğ•Šdâˆ’1superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, typical operations include comparing âŸ¨ğ’’,ğ’—ğŸâŸ©ğ’’subscriptğ’—1\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v_{1}}\right\rangleâŸ¨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© and âŸ¨ğ’’,ğ’—ğŸâŸ©ğ’’subscriptğ’—2\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v_{2}}\right\rangleâŸ¨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ©, or determining whether âŸ¨ğ’’,ğ’—âŸ©ğ’’ğ’—\left\langle\bm{q},\bm{v}\right\rangleâŸ¨ bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v âŸ© exceeds a certain threshold. These operations, however, require computing exact inner products, which have a cost of Oâ¢(d)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘O(d)italic_O ( italic_d ) per comparison and become expensive in high dimensions. To address this, we aim to design a computation-efficient probabilistic kernel function Kğ¾Kitalic_K that can approximate these comparisons with reduced cost and high success probability. In particular, we focus on the following two problems:

Both problems have various applications. The goal of ProblemÂ 1.1 aligns with that of CEOsÂ ceos under cosine distance (we will postpone the general case of inner product to Sec.Â 4), allowing the designed kernel function to be applied to tasks where CEOs is effective, such as Maximum Inner Product Search (MIPS)Â ceos , filtering of NN candidatesÂ Falconn++ , DBSCANÂ sDBSCAN , and more. On the other hand, the goal of ProblemÂ 1.2 is similar to that of PEOsÂ peos , making the corresponding kernel function well-suited for probabilistic routing tests in similarity graphs, which have demonstrated significant performance improvements over original graphs, such as HNSWÂ hnsw . In Sec.Â 4, we will further elaborate on the applications of these two probabilistic kernel functions.

Despite addressing different tasks, all the techniquesÂ ceos ; Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN ; peos mentioned above use Gaussian distribution to generate projection vectors and are built upon a common statistical result, as follows.

LemmaÂ 1.3 builds the relationship between angles and corresponding projection vectors. Actually, ğ’—âŠ¤â¢ğ’–maxsuperscriptğ’—topsubscriptğ’–max\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u_{\text{max}}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be viewed as an indicator of the cosine angle ğ’’âŠ¤â¢ğ’—superscriptğ’’topğ’—\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v. On the other hand, ğ’—âŠ¤â¢ğ’–maxsuperscriptğ’—topsubscriptğ’–max\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u_{\text{max}}}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be computed beforehand during the indexing phase and can be easily accessed during the query phase, making Kâ¢(ğ’’,ğ’—)=ğ’—âŠ¤â¢ğ’–maxğ¾ğ’’ğ’—superscriptğ’—topsubscriptğ’–maxK(\bm{q},\bm{v})=\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u_{\text{max}}}italic_K ( bold_italic_q , bold_italic_v ) = bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a suitable kernel function for various angle testing problems, e.g., ProblemÂ 1.1.

However, LemmaÂ 1.3 has a significant theoretical limitation: the relationshipÂ (1) relies on the assumption that the number of projection vectors mğ‘šmitalic_m tends to infinity. Since the evaluation time of projection vectors depends on mğ‘šmitalic_m, mğ‘šmitalic_m cannot be very large in practice. Moreover, sinceÂ Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN ; peos all used LemmaÂ 1.3 to derive their respective theoretical results, these results are also affected by this limitation, and the impact of mğ‘šmitalic_m becomes even harder to predict in these applications.

The starting point of our research is to overcome this limitation, and we make the following two key observations. (1) The Gaussian distribution used in LemmaÂ 1.3 is not essential. In fact, the only factor determining the estimation accuracy of ğ’’âŠ¤â¢ğ’—superscriptğ’’topğ’—\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v is the reference angle, that is, the angle between ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}bold_italic_q and ğ’–maxsubscriptğ’–max\bm{u_{\text{max}}}bold_italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. (2) By introducing a random rotation matrix, the reference angle becomes dependent on the structure of the projection vectors and is predictable.

Based on these two observations, we design new probabilistic kernel functions to solve problemsÂ 1.1 andÂ 1.2. Specifically, the contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

(1) The proposed kernel functions KS1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘†K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscriptğ¾2ğ‘†K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see eq.Â (2) and eq.Â (3)) rely on a reference-angle-based probabilistic relationship between angles in high-dimensional spaces and projected values. Compared with eq.Â (1), the new relationship (see relationshipÂ (4)) is deterministic without dependence on asymptotic condition. By theoretical analysis, we show that, the proposed kernel functions are effective for the ProblemsÂ 1.1 andÂ 1.2, and the smaller the reference angle is, the more accurate the kernel functions are (see LemmasÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3 ).

(2) To minimize the reference angle, we study the structure of the configuration of projection vectors (see Sec.Â 3.2). We propose two structures (see Alg.Â 1 and Alg.Â 2) that perform better than purely random projection (see Alg.Â 3), and we establish the relationship between the reference angle and the proposed structures (see LemmaÂ 3.5 and Fig.Â 4).

(3) Based on KS1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘†K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we propose a random-projection technique KS1 which can be used for CEOs-based tasksÂ ceos ; Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN . Based on KS2subscriptsuperscriptğ¾2ğ‘†K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we introduce a new routing test called the KS2 test which can be used to accelerate the graph-based Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search (ANNS)Â peos (see Sec.Â 4).

(4) We experimentally show that KS1 provides a slight accuracy improvement (up to 0.8%) over CEOs. In the ANNS task, we demonstrate that HNSW+KS2 improves the query-per-second (QPS) of the state-of-the-art approach HNSW+PEOsÂ peos by 10% â€“ 30%, along with a 5% reduction in index size.

2 Related Work

Due to space limitations, we focus on random projection techniques that are closely related to this work. An illustration comparing the proposed random projection technique with others can be found in Sec.Â B.1 and Fig.Â 3 in Appendix. Since the proposed kernel function is also used in similarity graphs for ANNS, a comprehensive discussion of ANNS solutions is provided in AppendixÂ B.2.

In high-dimensional Euclidean spaces, the estimation of angles via random-projection techniques, especially Locality Sensitive Hashing (LSH)Â IndykM98:approximate-nearest-neighbor ; Andoni2004:e2lsh ; AndoniI08:near-optimal-hashing , has a relatively long history. One classical LSH-based technique is SimHashÂ simhash , whose basic idea is to generate multiple hyperplanes and partition the original space into many cells such that two vectors falling into the same cell are likely to have a small angle between them. InÂ falconn , the authors proposed a different LSH-based technique called Falconn for angular distance, whose basic idea is to find the closest or furthest projection vector to the data vector and record this projection vector as a hash value, leading to better search performance than SimHash. Later, the authors inÂ ceos employed Concomitants of Extreme Order Statistics (CEOs) to identify the projection with the largest or smallest inner product with the data vector, as shown in LemmaÂ 1.3, and recorded the corresponding maximum or minimum projected value to obtain a more accurate estimation than using a hash value aloneÂ Falconn++ . Notably, CEOs can be used not only for angular distance but also for inner product estimation.

Due to its ease of implementation, CEOs has been employed in several similarity search tasksÂ ceos ; falconn ; sDBSCAN , as mentioned in Sec.Â 1. Additionally, CEOs has been used to accelerate similarity graphs, which are among the leading structures for Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search (ANNS). InÂ peos , by swapping the roles of query and data vectors in CEOs, the authors introduced a space-partitioning technique and proposed the PEOs test, which can be used to compare the objective angle with a fixed threshold under probabilistic guarantees. This test was incorporated into the routing mechanisms of similarity graphs and achieved significant search performance improvements over original graph structures like HNSWÂ hnsw and NSSGÂ nssg .

(2) (Deterministic relationship for angle testing) LemmaÂ 3.2 establishes a relationship between the objective angle Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• and the value of the function KS1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘†K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence, eq.Â (4) essentially describes a deterministic relationship. In contrast to the asymptotic relationship of CEOs, eq.Â (4) provides an exact relationship without additional assumptions.

(3) (Effectiveness of kernel functions) The above two lemmas show that, with a reasonable construction of Sğ‘†Sitalic_S such that the reference angle is small with high probability, KS1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘†K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscriptğ¾2ğ‘†K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can effectively address the corresponding angle testing problems. Specifically, the smaller the reference angle is, the more effective KS1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘†K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscriptğ¾2ğ‘†K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT become (By p2â¢(Ï•)subscriptğ‘2italic-Ï•p_{2}(\phi)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï• ), a smaller Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ leads to a smaller p2â¢(Ï•)subscriptğ‘2italic-Ï•p_{2}(\phi)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï• )).

(4) (Gaussian distribution is suboptimal) The fact that a smaller reference angle is favorable justifies the utilization of ZSâ¢(â‹…)subscriptğ‘ğ‘†â‹…Z_{S}(\cdot)italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ) and also implies that the Gaussian distribution is not an optimal choice for configuring Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, since in this case, the selected reference vector with the largest inner product with the query or data vector is not guaranteed to have the smallest reference angle.

Now, we are ready to explain Alg.Â 1 and Alg.Â 2 as follows.

(1) (Utilization of antipodal pairs and cross-polytopes) We use the antipodal pair or the cross-polytope as our building block for the following three reasons. (1) Since all the projection vectors are antipodal pairs, the evaluation time of projection vectors can be halved. (2) Both of two structures can ensure that the assumption ASâ¢(ğ’—)>0subscriptğ´ğ‘†ğ’—0A_{S}(\bm{v})>0italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) > 0 holds, such that the condition in LemmaÂ 3.3 is always satisfied. Although the results in the case m>2â¢dğ‘š2ğ‘‘m>2ditalic_m > 2 italic_d are unknown, we can rotate the fixed cross-polytope in random directions to generate multiple cross-polytopes until we obtain mğ‘šmitalic_m vectors, which explains the steps from 6 to 10 in Alg.Â 2.

(2) (Selection from random configurations) We can generate such mğ‘šmitalic_m points in the above way many times, which forms multiple Sğ‘†Sitalic_Sâ€™s. By LemmaÂ 3.4, we can use J~â¢(S,N)~ğ½ğ‘†ğ‘\tilde{J}(S,N)over~ start_ARG italic_J end_ARG ( italic_S , italic_N ) to approximately evaluate the performance of Jâ¢(S)ğ½ğ‘†J(S)italic_J ( italic_S ), and thus, among the generated Sğ‘†Sitalic_Sâ€™s, we select the configuration Spolsubscriptğ‘†polS_{\text{pol}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT corresponding to the maximal J~â¢(S,n)~ğ½ğ‘†ğ‘›\tilde{J}(S,n)over~ start_ARG italic_J end_ARG ( italic_S , italic_n ). (3) (Accuracy boosting via multiple levels) Clearly, increasing mğ‘šmitalic_m can lead to a smaller reference angle. 4 Applications to Similarity Search

In Sec.Â 4, we show how KS1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘†K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and KS2subscriptsuperscriptğ¾2ğ‘†K^{2}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be used in concrete applications.

4.1 Improvement on CEOs-Based Techniques

As for KS1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘†K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can use it to improve CEOs, which is used for Maximum Inner Product Search (MIPS) and further applied to accelerate LSH-based ANNSÂ falconn and DBSCANÂ sDBSCAN . Since CEOs is originally designed for inner products, we generalize KS1subscriptsuperscriptğ¾1ğ‘†K^{1}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to KS1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ¾superscript1â€²ğ‘†K^{1^{\prime}}_{S}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows to align with CEOs:

4.2 A New Probabilistic Test in Similarity Graph

This is the original task of PEOsÂ peos , where the authors introduce probabilistic routing into similarity graphs to accelerate the search. The definition of probabilistic routing is as follows.

InÂ peos , the authors proposed a (Î´,1âˆ’Ïµ)ğ›¿1italic-Ïµ(\delta,1-\epsilon)( italic_Î´ , 1 - italic_Ïµ )-routing test called PEOs test. During the traversal of the similarity graph, we check the exact distance from graph node wğ‘¤witalic_w to qğ‘qitalic_q only when ineq.Â (10) is satisfied; otherwise, we skip the computation of wğ‘¤witalic_w for efficiency. A complete graph-based algorithm equipped with the KS2 test can be found in Alg.Â 6. By LemmaÂ 3.3 and the same analysis inÂ peos , we can easily obtain the following result.

Corollary 4.2

The graph-based search equipped with the KS2 testÂ (10) is a (Î´,0.5)ğ›¿0.5(\delta,0.5)( italic_Î´ , 0.5 )-routing test.

Comparison with PEOs. Since PEOs also uses a Gaussian distribution to generate projection vectors in subspaces like CEOs, the estimation in ineq.Â (10) is more accurate than that of the PEOs test, as discussed earlier. In addition, the proposed test has two advantages:(1) ineq.Â (10) is much simpler than the testing inequality in the PEOs test, resulting in higher evaluation efficiency; (2) ineq.Â (10) requires fewer constants to be stored, leading to a smaller index size compared to that of PEOs.

Complexity analysis. For the time complexity, for every edge eğ‘’eitalic_e, the computation of the LHS of ineq.Â (10) requires Lğ¿Litalic_L lookups in the table and Lâˆ’1ğ¿1L-1italic_L - 1 additions, while the computation of the RHS of ineq.Â (10) requires two additions and one multiplication. By using SIMD, we can perform the KS2 test for 16161616 edges simultaneously. For the space complexity, for each edge, we need to store Lğ¿Litalic_L bytes to recover ğ’’ğ’ŠâŠ¤â¢ğ’–ğ’†â¢[ğ’Š]ğ’Šsuperscriptsubscriptğ’’ğ’Štopsubscriptsuperscriptğ’–ğ’Šğ’†delimited-[]ğ’Š\bm{{q_{i}}^{\top}u^{i}_{e[i]}}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_e bold_[ bold_italic_i bold_] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, along with two scalars, that is, ASâ¢(ğ’—)â¢â€–ğ’˜â€–2/(2â¢â€–ğ’†â€–)subscriptğ´ğ‘†ğ’—superscriptnormğ’˜22normğ’†A_{S}(\bm{v})\|\bm{w}\|^{2}/(2\|\bm{e}\|)italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) âˆ¥ bold_italic_w âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 2 âˆ¥ bold_italic_e âˆ¥ ) and ASâ¢(ğ’—)/â€–ğ’†â€–subscriptğ´ğ‘†ğ’—normğ’†A_{S}(\bm{v})/\|\bm{e}\|italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_v ) / âˆ¥ bold_italic_e âˆ¥, which are quantized using scalar quantization to enable fast computation of the RHS of ineq.Â (10).

5 Experiments

All experiments were conducted on a PC equipped with an Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6258R CPU @ 2.70GHz. KS1 and KS2 were implemented in C++. The ANNS experiments used 64 threads for indexing and a single CPU for searching. We evaluated our methods on six high-dimensional real-world datasets: Word, GloVe1M, GloVe2M, Tiny, GIST, and SIFT. Detailed statistics for these datasets are provided in AppendixÂ C.1. More experimental results can be found in AppendixÂ C.

5.1 Comparison with CEOs

As demonstrated in Sec.Â 4.1, the results of CEOs are directly used to accelerate other similarity search processesÂ Falconn++ ; sDBSCAN . In this context, we focus solely on the improvement of CEOs itself. Specifically, we show that KS1, equipped with the structures Ssymâ¢(m,1)subscriptğ‘†symğ‘š1S_{\text{sym}}(m,1)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m , 1 ) and Spolâ¢(m,1)subscriptğ‘†polğ‘š1S_{\text{pol}}(m,1)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m , 1 ), can slightly outperform CEOs(mğ‘šmitalic_m) on the original task of CEOs, that is, kğ‘˜kitalic_k-MIPS, where mğ‘šmitalic_m denotes the number of projection vectors and was set to 2048, following the standard configuration of the original CEOs. Since the only difference among the compared approaches is the configuration of the projection vectors, we use a unified algorithm (see construction of projection structure Alg.Â 4 and MIPS query processing Alg.Â 5 in Appendix) with the configuration of projection vectors as an input to compare their recall rates. From the results in Tab.Â 1, we observe that: (1) in most cases, KS1 with the two proposed structures achieves slightly better performance than CEOs, supporting our claim that a smaller reference angle yields a more accurate estimation, and (2) Spolsubscriptğ‘†polS_{\text{pol}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generally achieves a higher recall rate than Ssymsubscriptğ‘†symS_{\text{sym}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, verifying that a configuration closer to the best covering yields better performance.

5.2 ANNS Performance

We chose ScaNNÂ Scann , HNSWÂ hnsw , and HNSW+PEOsÂ peos as our baselines, where ScaNN is a state-of-the-art quantization-based approach that performs better than IVFPQFS, and HNSW+PEOsÂ peos is a state-of-the-art graph-based approach that outperforms FINGERÂ FINGER and Glass. Similar to HNSW+PEOs, KS2 is implemented on HNSW, and the corresponding approach is named HNSW+KS2. The detailed parameter settings of all compared approaches can be found in AppendixÂ C.1, and additional experimental results can also be found in AppendixÂ C.

(1) Index size and indexing time. Regarding indexing time, after constructing the HNSW graph, we require an additional 42s, 164s, 165s, 188s, 366s, and 508s to align the edges and build the KS2 testing structure on Word, GloVe1M, GIST, GloVe2M, SIFT, and Tiny, respectively. This overhead is less than 25% of the graph construction time. In practice, users can reduce the parameter efc to shorten indexing time while still preserving the superior search performance of HNSW+KS2. As for the index size, it largely depends on the parameter Lğ¿Litalic_L, which will be discussed later.

(2) Query performance. From the results in Fig.Â 1, we make the following observations. (i) Except for Word, HNSW+KS2 achieves the best performance among all compared methods. In particular, HNSW+KS2 accelerates HNSW by a factor of 2.5 to 3, and is 1.1 to 1.3 times faster than HNSW+PEOs, demonstrating the superiority of KS2 over PEOs. (ii) Compared with ScaNN, the advantage of HNSW+KS2 is especially evident in the recall region below 85%, highlighting the high efficiency of the routing test. On the other hand, in the high-recall region for Word, ScaNN outperforms HSNW+KS2 due to the connectivity issues of HNSW.

(3) Impact of Lğ¿Litalic_L. The only tunable parameter in KS2 is Lğ¿Litalic_L. Generally speaking, the larger Lğ¿Litalic_L is, the larger the index size is. On the other hand, a larger Lğ¿Litalic_L can lead to a smaller reference angle and yield better search performance. Hence, Lğ¿Litalic_L can be used to achieve different trade-offs between index size and search performance. In Fig.Â 2, we show the impact of Lğ¿Litalic_L on index size and search performance. From the results, we have the following observations. (i) The index size of HNSW+KS2 is slightly smaller than that of HNSW+PEOs due to the storage of fewer scalars. (ii) When dâ€²=d/Lsuperscriptğ‘‘â€²ğ‘‘ğ¿d^{\prime}=d/Litalic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_d / italic_L is around 16, HNSW+KS2 achieves the best search performance. This is because a larger Lğ¿Litalic_L also leads to longer testing time and dâ€²=16superscriptğ‘‘â€²16d^{\prime}=16italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 16 is sufficient to obtain a small enough reference angle.

6 Conclusions

In this paper, we studied two angle-testing problems in high-dimensional Euclidean spaces: angle comparison and angle thresholding. To address these problems, we proposed two probabilistic kernel functions that are based on reference angles and are easy to implement. To minimize the reference angle, we further investigated the structure of the projection vectors and established a relationship between the expected value of the reference angle and the proposed projection vector structure. Based on these two functions, we introduced the KS1 projection and the KS2 test. In the experiments, we showed that KS1 achieves a slight accuracy improvement over CEOs, and that HNSW+KS2 delivers better search performance than the existing state-of-the-art ANNS approaches.

Appendix B Supplementary Materials

B.1 Illustration of Random Projection Techniques for Angle Estimation

An illustration is shown in Fig.Â 3. In this figure, ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}bold_italic_q represents a query and ğ’—ğ’—\bm{v}bold_italic_v is a data vector. For Falconn, if ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}bold_italic_q and ğ’—ğ’—\bm{v}bold_italic_v are mapped to the same vector, they are considered close. For CEOs and KS1, the inner product ğ’—âŠ¤â¢ğ’–superscriptğ’—topğ’–\bm{v}^{\top}\bm{u}bold_italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u, where ğ’–ğ’–\bm{u}bold_italic_u is the projection vector closest to ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}bold_italic_q, is computed to obtain a more accurate estimate of ğ’’âŠ¤â¢ğ’—superscriptğ’’topğ’—\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v. The key difference between CEOs and KS1 lies in the structure of the projection vectors. While CEOs uses projection vectors sampled from a Gaussian distribution, KS1 employs a more balanced structure in which all projection vectors lie on the surface of a sphere. By applying a random rotation matrix and constructing a spherical cross-section centered at ğ’’ğ’’\bm{q}bold_italic_q, we can establish the required statistical relationship between ğ’’âŠ¤â¢ğ’–superscriptğ’’topğ’–\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{u}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u and ğ’’âŠ¤â¢ğ’—superscriptğ’’topğ’—\bm{q}^{\top}\bm{v}bold_italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_v.

B.2 ANNS and Similarity Graphs

As one of the most fundamental problems, approximate nearest neighbor search (ANNS) has seen a surge of interest in recent years, leading to the development of numerous approaches across different paradigms. These include tree-based methodsÂ [10], hashing-based methodsÂ [3, 20, 1, 4, 26], vector quantization (VQ)-based methodsÂ [19, 15, 5, 16], learning-based methodsÂ [17, 21], and graph-based methodsÂ [23, 27, 14, 13].

Among these, graph-based methods are widely regarded as the state-of-the-art. Currently, three main types of optimizations are used to enhance their search performance: (1) improved edge-selection strategies, (2) more effective routing techniques, and (3) quantization of raw vectors. These approaches are generally orthogonal to one another. Since the proposed structure, PEOs, belongs to the second category, we briefly introduce several highly relevant works below. TOGG-KMC[29] and HCNNG[24] use KD-trees to determine the direction of the query and restrict the search to points in that direction. While this estimation is computationally efficient, it results in relatively low query accuracy, limiting their improvements over HNSW[23]. FINGER[9] examines all neighbors and estimates their distances to the query. Specifically, for each node, FINGER locally generates promising projection vectors to define a subspace, then uses collision counting which is similar to SimHash to approximate distances within each visited subspace. Learn-to-RouteÂ [6] learns a routing function using auxiliary representations that guide optimal navigation from the starting vertex to the nearest neighbor. Recently, the authors ofÂ [22] proposed PEOs, which leverages space partitioning and random projection techniques to estimate a random variable representing the angle between each neighbor and the query vector. By aggregating projection information from multiple subspaces, PEOs substantially reduces the variance of this estimated distribution, significantly improving query accuracy.

B.3 Algorithms Related to KS1 and KS2

Alg.Â 4 and Alg.Â 5 are used to compare the probing accuracies of CEOs and KS1, while Alg.Â 6 presents the graph-based search equipped with the KS2 test.

B.4 Numerical Computation of Reference angle

Fig.Â 4 shows the numerical values of the lower bounds (the RHS of ineq.Â (8)) under different pairs of (m,L)ğ‘šğ¿(m,L)( italic_m , italic_L ). From the results, we observe that increasing Lğ¿Litalic_L significantly raises the cosine of the reference angle, whereas a linear increase in mğ‘šmitalic_m leads to only a slow growth in the cosine of the reference angle, which explains why we need to introduce parameter Lğ¿Litalic_L into our projection structure.

Appendix C Additional Experiments

C.1 Datasets and Parameter Settings

The statistic of six datasets used in this paper is shown in Tab.Â 2. The parameter settings of all compared methods are shown as follows.

(1) CEOs: The number of projection vectors, mğ‘šmitalic_m, was set to 2048, following the standard setting in the original paperÂ [25].

(2) KS1: For KS1, Lğ¿Litalic_L was fixed to 1, as multiple levels are not necessary for angle comparison. The number of projection vectors, mğ‘šmitalic_m, was also set to 2048, consistent with CEOs. We evaluated both KS1(S=Ssymâ¢(2048,1)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†sym20481S=S_{\text{sym}}(2048,1)italic_S = italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2048 , 1 )) and KS1(S=Spolâ¢(2048,1)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†pol20481S=S_{\text{pol}}(2048,1)italic_S = italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2048 , 1 )).

(3) HNSW: Mğ‘€Mitalic_M was set to 32. The parameter efc was set to 1000 for SIFT, Tiny, and GIST, and to 2000 for Word, GloVe1M, and GloVe2M.

(4) ScaNN: The Dimensions_per_block was set to 4 for Tiny and GIST, and to 2 for the other datasets. num_leaves was set to 2000. The other user-specified parameters were tuned to achieve the best trade-off curves.

(5) HNSW+PEOs: Following the suggestions inÂ [22], we set Lğ¿Litalic_L to 8, 10, 15, 15, 16, and 20 for the six real datasets, sorted in ascending order of dimension. Additionally, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ was set to 0.2, and m=256ğ‘š256m=256italic_m = 256 to ensure that each vector ID could be encoded with a single byte.

(6) HNSW+KS2: Sğ‘†Sitalic_S was fixed to Ssymâ¢(m,L)subscriptğ‘†symğ‘šğ¿S_{\text{sym}}(m,L)italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sym end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_m , italic_L ). The only tunable parameter is Lğ¿Litalic_L, as mğ‘šmitalic_m must be fixed at 256 to ensure that each vector ID is encoded with a single byte. Since the parameter Lğ¿Litalic_L in KS2 plays a similar role to that in PEOs, we set Lğ¿Litalic_L to the same value in HNSW+PEOs to eliminate the influence of Lğ¿Litalic_L in the comparison.
